												The game is not as exact as the original, in design and gameplay - There are bugs and problems.It is a cross-platform hybrid FPS/Tower Defence game with online matchmaking of various modes and styles, featuring a few customisable character classes and an abundance of weapons, towers and perks. Maps are often not limited to the tower grid and sometimes cover vast explorable distances. Enemies are varied in type and offer ideas for different tactics and strategies though somewhat limited in count. The last wave in a round frequently provides additional challenges and frustrations.So the game offers an interesting blend of thoughtful tower defense and mindless shooting, all wrapped around cool explosions and a chance to deviate from regular gameplay.

												This is an oddity but a singular pleasure in tower defense multiplayer gaming. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												The Sanctum series really set the standards of FPS-Tower Defense hybrid. However, Sanctum 2 is very much different than the first Sanctum. While Sanctum is 90% tower defense and 10% hero defense, Sanctum 2 is 50% tower defense and 50% hero defense. This means you can't just build-and-forget like the first Sanctum, where you just have to have enough decent towers and a well-made maze and you'll make it through the waves.In Sanctum 2, you'll have to fire your guns just as often as your towers or you'll lose the wave. This makes for a more immersive game which requires more input and interaction from players, and proper strategies will determine the border between victory or annihilation. Not to mention you can get killed if the wave mobs get close to you.Add a little RPG element to the mix where you get to select a character, equip his/her weapons, select your towers and skills obtained by leveling up, and you have yourself a semi-complex game that will keep you occupied for many hours and offers high replayability value.Pick up a bunch of friends and buy the pack for this game, and you can't go wrong. Most definitely recommended, better than a lot of games currently in the market, and it is very affordable and worth the money.Without a doubt, 8 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2013
												While Sanctum 2 is a good game, I think the original is better. If you enjoyed the original, the sequel is worth playing. But if youre new to Sanctum, start with the first game, especially if you plan to play alone. There have been several changes to gameplay mechanics, a couple of which are improvements. Some enemies will attack the player instead of just running to the core, and bosses can destroy towers. If you cant afford to fully upgrade a tower you can partially upgrade for a small stat boost. But other changes are restrictive. You can only build 15 towers per map. There are no mid game checkpoints - fail and its back to wave 1. Loadouts are smaller (2 weapons and 4 towers compared to 3 and 6 previously) which means that you cant fully appreciate the tactical depth unless you play with a coop partner who brings different gear. A new range of perks have been added, but the ability to upgrade guns has been removed, and many weapons/towers/perks are locked until you grind enough XP.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Really fun hybrid/FPS TD game. Before the level you pick your character, weapon and the perks and towers you want to equip. You also unlock more as you rank up and can gain more xp with applying buffs (feats of strength) to give you bonus XP. Before the waves start you run around building the blocks/foundations and then spend money to build the towers you've equipped in the loadout or upgrade them. Then you start the wave and while the towers you built are doing their job you just run around blowing up alien-like creatures and gunning them down. I love TD games/maps and this is really fun! Even better I got this for $3 USD on the Lunar sale instead of $15.  Still worth it either way, though. It's a must-buy, especially at sale price.Pros:-Fun as fun can be-Graphics are decent and pretty, nice environment and textures.-Running around blowing things up while towers work is fun.-Maze maze maze.-Heaps of perks and towers to unlock.-Can play solo, co-op or online. Private or public.-Bosses can smash your towers so prioritise them or build empty blocks on the outer perimeter.Cons:-Difficulty scaling isn't perfect. I'm not sure if it scales with more players if you play online/co-op. Starting levels were quite hard, middle levels quite easy,-Needs more content, although the game is cheap.-Repetitive like most TD games, not too[/] much though, just that there's not much different strats you can do, although tactical juxtaposition perk can change things up a bit.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												On the surface, Sanctum 2 is a basic tower defense shooter, with much better than indie graphics and voice overs (I want to marry Sweet), and a strange fixation on irrelevant details (why all this modeling of bars and security points that have nothing to do with the game?).  In contrast to Dungeon Grinders.. I mean Defenders, Sanctum eschews the farming and looting in favor of straight game play.  It does have experience and levels, but they're mostly a minor annoyance.  Like DD, the first person shooter element isn't strongly emphasized as the enemies are all very predictable and tower placement usually dominates your chances of success.Where Sanctum really shines is the point after you've beaten the normal levels by randomly throwing down some towers and running wildly around blasting everything.  Flip on all the bad guy boosts and suddenly you have a very serious co-op puzzle game.  Which perks to take, what guns, and how to lay out your towers become hard questions, with different answers for every map.  Climbing the leaderboard becomes a competitive challenge.If you enjoy cooperatively solving hard optimization problems, I strongly recommend Sanctum 2 with a friend.Sanctum 2 does have some weak points.  The experience/level system just gets in the way and should've been scrapped.    There are too many perks and even when you know them all, it can be hard to find the one you want.  Number of players scaling is sometimes a factor.  Hoard avoided this by having specific maps for specific numbers of players.  Sanctum tries to pretend boosting the health of enemies is close enough.  It isn't and it makes leaderboard comparisons problematic.  The mind control tower introduced in the dlc substantially changes the game and ruins the leaderboard for people without the dlc.  The developers should've had separate ladders for dlc and without.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Sanctum 2 is a Tower Defense/FPS hybrid game.1. Choose a private or public match (solo, with friends or/and strangers)2. Chosse your map. (4 regions, each region have 4 stages).3. Choose from four unique character (four classes).4. Choose your weapons (primary and secundary).5. Choose your perks, (max of three) affecting your caracther, the core, or the gun.6. Manage your resources (walls and towers).6.1. Build your maze (You gather new walls each wave).6.2. Place you towers (You gather scrap each wave).7. Fight hordes of enemies (various waves).+ With multiple players monsters become more powerful but also more recourses are avaliable, making the maps more easy.+ Plays like the best FPS(s), controls are smooth (very important IMO).+ Monsters show damage taken which is nice.+ Sound and music suits the game (actually the music is really really good).+ There are interesting Easter eggs.+ The chat features Text to Speech (sounds silly, but is amazing).- In public matches people can hop in and destroy your walls and towers (trolls).- Sometimes you could find yourself trapped in the environment requiring you to suicide.- Screenshots make justice, but bould be better optimized. Please turn off the Bloom.- Some towers are simply sub-par to others.Sincerally, I'm more excited for Sanctum3 than other blockbusters.[9/10]

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
TL;DR:While it's not a game for everyone, if you enjoyed tower defence but got bored with the monotony, get this game and hail the triumphant return of Tower Defence.Full Review:It was several years ago, and I'd had enough of the tower defence genre. With countless flash and mobile games that felt almost like carbon copies of each other, it had pretty much stagnated in my eyes. It looked as if the games I had once loved was dead.And then I discovered Sanctum.Sure, the internet connection I had at the time made it impossible for me to play co-op online, but with what little FPS skill I could muster I made due, and I absolutely loved it.Flash-forward to late October 2013, when I found Sanctum 2 on sale. I immediately snapped it up and started playing, and I was far from dissapointed. Coffee Stain had used the 2 years between Sanctum and this game to truly make it worthy of being "the sequel to the world’s first Tower Defense/FPS hybrid game." For those of you that played the original, the biggest difference by far is the new resource system, which now has seperate units for constructing the tower bases that outline the maze and the towers that shoot the creeps ("Lumes"). New characters open up brand new strategies for demolishing the relentless horde. Gone now are the teleporter towers, now made pretty much unnesesary by smaller, more focused maps. Recycling towers also gives you all the credits put into them now, with the option to revert to only getting half your resources back avaliable in the "Hardcore Mode" Feat of Strength, which also includes no respawn. There are other fairly large differences (was there a 15 tower limit in the original?), but I found that they, like the ones mentioned above, actually added to the fun of the game so much I didn't actually care.For those of you who haven't played the original, this game is possibly the most rewarding co-op game I have ever played, effortlessly combining high-brow Tower Defence strategy with fast-paced, cooperative First Person Shooter action. So for those of you who, like me, became tired of simply observing your towers attempt to beat back the horde, come join us. LOEK III can always use a few more Guardians.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												The game is not as exact as the original, in design and gameplay - There are bugs and problems.It is a cross-platform hybrid FPS/Tower Defence game with online matchmaking of various modes and styles, featuring a few customisable character classes and an abundance of weapons, towers and perks. Maps are often not limited to the tower grid and sometimes cover vast explorable distances. Enemies are varied in type and offer ideas for different tactics and strategies though somewhat limited in count. The last wave in a round frequently provides additional challenges and frustrations.So the game offers an interesting blend of thoughtful tower defense and mindless shooting, all wrapped around cool explosions and a chance to deviate from regular gameplay.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												The first flavor is sweetness, like a sweet pickle, which I actually don’t care for. But after there’s a strong and pleasant herbal dill note along with a weird sort of garlic flavor. The tartness that emulates vinegar comes in slowly. Overall, it’s a good likeness of a pickle in dissolvable form. I would have liked a little less sweet, which I understand is hard to do with candy, but perhaps a dash of salt. Mostly, it lacks the texture, that crunch, the coldness from the fridge that are elements I enjoy in my pickle. My mouth never quite watered during the experience like it does with some good, refrigerator-cold, fresh pickles.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Sanctum 1 was a tower defense game with FPS mechanics.  Sanctum 2 has much more limited maze design opportunities but adds Borderlands-style class mechanics with perks, different loadouts, etc.   This changed the game a lot which seems to have upset a lot of Sanctum 1 purists.  However, the changes actually justify the sequel since they amount to a huge overhaul of the game and not simply a slight modification of the original.  The game is designed well, controls well, and runs pretty well.  I've had very occasional glitches but it's better than par for the most part.  Sanctum 2 ends up being much more fun in multiplayer than singleplayer - so much so that I'd really only recommend getting it if you have a friend or two to play with.  That said, it is REALLY fun in mutliplayer and since you can often pick it up for $5 per copy, it's great value.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												Sanctum 2 is an enjoyable co-op game combining tower defense and FPS gameplay in a neat integrated package. You have a build phase during which you build your maze and deploy or upgrade tower weapons. This whole process is much more streamlined than the original game. Once your team is happy with the set up you activate the wave. Then it is shoot to kill using your own personal weapons. This part of the game is also more satisfying than the original because there seems to be less clumping of the enemies and therefore less "Blast away without aiming" style gun play. The game is certainly well equipped to provide many evenings of inexpensive fun for a group of friends.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												What can I say about this game? I could discuss its tight controls and fun combat. I could talk about the beautiful art style or the ever expanding loadout configurations. We could even focus on some of the most kick♥♥♥♥♥DLC I've ever seen. But that isn't what sold me this game. Instead, I want to explain the studio's personal touches.First of all, all of the levels have hidden in-game items. This turns each level into a scavenger hunt which forces the player to take a tour of the enviroment and possibly uncover another hidden gem. Easter eggs/hidden rooms. This game is full of them! From functioning arcade machines to secret codes, this game is full of fun surprises. It adds character and humor to another masterpiece from Coffee Stain Studios.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game does a fantastic job combining the enjoyment of strategizing in a tower defense with the fast-paced action of a shooter. Unlike a lot of games that try to combine TD with another genre, one style tends to fall short of the other in terms of importance to game content and/or quality. That is not the case in Sanctum. I saw it as a bold move combining the slow meticulous strategy of tower defense with the fast-paced twitch style of FPS but this game knew what it was doing. The tower defense aspect is fun and engaging and not as slow and monotonous as it often is in games like Dungeon Defenders, while the FPS aspect is diverse and rewarding with a multitude of weapons and augmentations.

												I really like the concept of this game.  The ability to move blocks and towers, and swap out towers without penalty, are great touches.  The game was completely different from what I was expecting, and I wish I would have heard of this game sooner.  I love finding a game that introduces me to something new and enjoyable.  Simple and enjoyable.  The maps vary enough to keep things from becoming too redundant.  I like that I can go back to previous maps, and try to set my own goals, such as: fewest blocks and towers used, all turrets, all ground pounders, nothing but blocks, and anything else that creates a challenge.  I really enjoy standing at the exit of a long maze of turrets, just blasting away at those mobs that thought they were going to make it to the end.  Chain-reaction exploding mobs anyone?

												I always enjoyed the tower defense games in my ipod, but for the PC, wow, and its multiplayer? i was awe-struck again! The multiplayer is populated and you can even solo if you wish, the communication system is excellent, the game reads your messages through microsoft Sam which is funny. You level up, get new guns, towers, abilities, etc. So many missions. I just got this game for $2.24 but i would still pay $15 for it. I just got the game today and i already spent 13 hours on it.. i feel like its only beed 4 or 5 hours. Time flys by and it gets intense! You rely on your team members to think up new ways on how to succeed. I went ahead and purchased the 4-Pack for $6.74 as a gift for my friends who want to enjoy this game. I want to add one more thing before I post my review - the abuse/kicking system is well thought out. There is no vote-kicking if somebody has gone insane, the host has full control and can easily remove trouble-makers. I have yet to see anybody goin crazy, the players all have a common goal to win and work together. Great game, really great game for a great price. $2.24 for this game? thats the cost of a cheese burger, if you missed the 85% off deal, $15 is just the price of a large pizza. Awesome game A++

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												On the surface, Sanctum 2 is a basic tower defense shooter, with much better than indie graphics and voice overs (I want to marry Sweet), and a strange fixation on irrelevant details (why all this modeling of bars and security points that have nothing to do with the game?).  In contrast to Dungeon Grinders.. I mean Defenders, Sanctum eschews the farming and looting in favor of straight game play.  It does have experience and levels, but they're mostly a minor annoyance.  Like DD, the first person shooter element isn't strongly emphasized as the enemies are all very predictable and tower placement usually dominates your chances of success.Where Sanctum really shines is the point after you've beaten the normal levels by randomly throwing down some towers and running wildly around blasting everything.  Flip on all the bad guy boosts and suddenly you have a very serious co-op puzzle game.  Which perks to take, what guns, and how to lay out your towers become hard questions, with different answers for every map.  Climbing the leaderboard becomes a competitive challenge.If you enjoy cooperatively solving hard optimization problems, I strongly recommend Sanctum 2 with a friend.Sanctum 2 does have some weak points.  The experience/level system just gets in the way and should've been scrapped.    There are too many perks and even when you know them all, it can be hard to find the one you want.  Number of players scaling is sometimes a factor.  Hoard avoided this by having specific maps for specific numbers of players.  Sanctum tries to pretend boosting the health of enemies is close enough.  It isn't and it makes leaderboard comparisons problematic.  The mind control tower introduced in the dlc substantially changes the game and ruins the leaderboard for people without the dlc.  The developers should've had separate ladders for dlc and without.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Really fun hybrid/FPS TD game. Before the level you pick your character, weapon and the perks and towers you want to equip. You also unlock more as you rank up and can gain more xp with applying buffs (feats of strength) to give you bonus XP. Before the waves start you run around building the blocks/foundations and then spend money to build the towers you've equipped in the loadout or upgrade them. Then you start the wave and while the towers you built are doing their job you just run around blowing up alien-like creatures and gunning them down. I love TD games/maps and this is really fun! Even better I got this for $3 USD on the Lunar sale instead of $15.  Still worth it either way, though. It's a must-buy, especially at sale price.Pros:-Fun as fun can be-Graphics are decent and pretty, nice environment and textures.-Running around blowing things up while towers work is fun.-Maze maze maze.-Heaps of perks and towers to unlock.-Can play solo, co-op or online. Private or public.-Bosses can smash your towers so prioritise them or build empty blocks on the outer perimeter.Cons:-Difficulty scaling isn't perfect. I'm not sure if it scales with more players if you play online/co-op. Starting levels were quite hard, middle levels quite easy,-Needs more content, although the game is cheap.-Repetitive like most TD games, not too[/] much though, just that there's not much different strats you can do, although tactical juxtaposition perk can change things up a bit.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Sanctum 2 is a very nice polished and overall well made game in which the developers managed to combine both the fps and the tower defense elements very well. It also has a very big variety of both towers and weapons so you can try and use multiple combination since all of them are 100% valid for gameplay use, making it so that you can create your very own build that might or might not work depending the way you use them and the situation.Personally I have found Sanctum 2 to be able to keep me entertained for hours either on a solo gameplay or in co-op with difficult stages that required me to change my strategies, tactics and placement in order to pass it. Also, just like in any good tower defense game, there was almost always a new enemy to encounter, sometime it was a support enemy healer or buffer, or others where heavily armored with weak spots or just some fast moving targets that you had to be careful about because they could one shot you my running over you. Also the voice acting is amazing the dialogues where nice and appealing to each character alike. The story might not have been just as good as the gameplay or other previously mentioned aspects of the game but it certaintly is good enough to at least keep you interested in it.So over all this game is really fun and balanced, as I said before the arsenal provided to you is really nice and useful, it might not have such a big replay value appart from finding some hidden stuff in some maps and trying a new build, but nonetheless it's a very nice, polished game with a great feelling in its gameplay, the controls are smooth, the only bad thing is that you can get stuck in some places and either have to suicide or just be unable to move but that doesn't really happens often unleash you just jump around all the map :P, and it has a very decent co-op.Oh and also there is free comics. That's always good ain't it? :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Man, Sanctum 2 is one of my favorite games of all time. The guys that made Goat Simulator made this game first, and it sure is a gem that should be played by everyone. I love how it uses the tower defense genre simultaneously with some first-person shooter gameplay, and without any of the clutter many games like Orcs Must Die and PVZ: Garden Warefare have shown. There's some basic class customization that's simple but changes each level's approach immensely. Also, multiplayer is awesome, especially in later levels where teamwork is key to victory. I didn't buy the DLC, but I know I should have since it unlocks tons of valuable features that are definitely worth the extra cash. Hilarious and interactive easter eggs can be found all over the normal looking levels too. One level actually has a full-on arcade in the sky where you can play mini-games, it's awesome. Grab some friends to play with, and check this game out if you haven't yet.Rating: 10/10Recommended Price: $15

												Compared to Sanctum 1 this focuses a bit more on the shooter part than the tower defense part. The resources and tower limit were both known about before release. The resources definitely needs work, would like to see a few more towers available each wave as well. The tower limit makes you think of placement even more, and I have only hit the cap once so far. Would recommend buying the game but waiting on the Season Pass for now.

Posted: January 10, 2016
												This game incorporates a tower defence theme with an fps so effortlessly its beautiful. The graphics are good, weapons and towers a great, the maps are all creative, while i do wish there where more variety of types of modes (rn there is sniper, shotgun, and rifle characters). Its not very difficult to get into the game at first, the tutorial is easy to comprehend and teaches you basically everything you need to know. The only hitch of this game... unless you have more than 1 friend, this game will get boring very quick. I recommend this game to anyone who's a social monster outside of the gaming realm. 10/10 would get myself a friend to play this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												If you liked Sanctum or are interested in tower defense games then you will probably love Sanctum 2! On top of what the original offers, it has new maps and several new enemies, weapons, and towers. Even cooler are some of the other new additions: you now get to select one of 4 characters/classes each time you play, the characters gain levels, and other than weapons and towers you also get abilities for your character to customize them further to your style. They also made coop play easier, and you can play any of the maps or campaign solo or with friends, or join other random players if you want. They also added some challenge parameters you can toggle if you choose like increasing the speed of the enemies or giving them regeneration and so on. Definitely worth picking up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I and my friends loved sanctum1 and for us, this game seemed like a no brainer purchase.  Over a year later I come back to see if they fixed any of the grievances people had on launch and it looks like they haven't really done much since on day one, one of the devs was flaming people and telling them "Just go play Sanctum 1 then."   This game isn't horrible, but compared to what it could have been it is just a big disappointment.  The dev team fell victim to a common mistake in gaming where they get rid of old (good) features and add some new ones instead.  IMO they could've had both.  Whereas the first game could easily be given an 8/10 by me, this one sits at a 7/10.  So why the negative? Because the developers made it clear on day one that they'd rather you go play Santcum 1 than spend your money on this second-rate sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2013
												 This game is really quite fun. I liked Sanctum, though I had trouble getting into it, it seemed a bit too daunting to me in terms of what it demanded from me. I had no qualms with the mazing aspect, though allocating money to many different areas on the game field was very daunting. Sanctum 2 fixes all that. All resources earned are decided to mazing. One can easily and respectibly call this a sequel, in that it not only adds new content, but it improves the original in just about every aspect, while still sticking to the core of the game. Don't expect the exact same as Sanctum 1. The maps are smaller, though there are many more of them. I would recommend buying Sanctum 2 now for a great summer experience! This game has incredibly high replayability in trying to earn spots on the leaderboards based on the number of waves survived in survival mode, as well as in trying out different strategies, and in just playing with others. With much more content promised through DLCs and a large amount of existing content, what reason is there to not get a game as awesome as Sanctum 2? If you are a fan of Strategy and First Person Shooters, this is for sure a game to check out.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Sanctum 2 is a great game if you want some casual co-op with your friends. It's as deep or simple as you want it to be and is a really good as a "pick up put down". Lovers of classic tower defence games can immersive themselves into their mazes round after round, rebuilding and reimagining the map as they see fit when they see fit, while the FPS half of the game is equally entertaining and allows for you to get dirty with your creations while adding even more strategy to the mix.Conceptually simple and easy to understand Sanctum 2 can be picked up and played by almost anyone, anytime, with no shortage of depth to the game and without being tediously repetitive.Loved it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This is, quite simply, the best co-op tower defense game ever made. That's not a huge claim because there aren't that many of them in the first place, but for someone who really loves the gerne like me this game really is a blessing.Its production values are high, which means that the ingame comics, the graphics, the sound and the effects are all top-notch (especially considering the price when it was on sale or in the Humble Bundle).The way the game is played is simple, it's a Dungeon Defenders-esque TD+shooter where you place blocks in squares on the map in a way that makes the enemies lose as much time as possible. Those blocks act as walls and as tower bases, which means you can either leave them there or build towers on top of them.There is also a metagame, as you can level up and unlock more weapons, more towers/tower slots, more weapons and more perks/perk slots.There is not much grinding as far as I have seen: you won't need to endlessly repeat old levels to be good enough to make it to the next one, although you will occasionally hit a wall where you're going to need to replay previous stages.The variety in weapons, enemies and towers is more than satisfactory, and you're going to find out each enemy's weak spot soon enough, as they try to make it as obvious as possible (for example, there's one type of enemy that will take literally 0 damage from the front, so you need to distract him with something else as you hit him from behind).One thing I will say about the difficulty though is that finishing the game solo is pretty much impossible. This game was made with co-op in mind, and if you don't have anyone to play with you better either find someone or join public servers, as it's really the only viable way to play this game.And speaking of public servers, you MIGHT have a problem with latency with this particular game. I couldn't connect to any pub games without horrific lag, and couldn't even play with a friend that lives relatively close to me.However, if you happen to stumble upon this problem, I have a solution for you: Tunngle.Just download it, google "Sanctum 2 Tunngle" and play there. It is not illegal in any way, so don't worry. It will create a fake LAN server for you to play on, without lag (assuming your co-op buddies don't have terrible internet).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Sanctum 2 is definitely worth the purchase.  The game is difficult but not too difficult or frustrating like most Tower Defense games.  The difference here is that you actually have control of the game in a FPS way.  Not only do you place walls, towers, and other goodies, but you are also in the arena fighting the waves first hand.There are a few issues with the game.   For one playing by yourself is just not fun.  Difficulty scales with number of players but teamwork is far superior than lone wolfing.  Another issue is the controls being awkward.  Playing with a controller makes things easier, since the game is made for the Xbox 360.  But what makes the games' controls awkward is that you have to understand that it's an FPS so you also have to place/upgrade/sell the walls/turrets/dispensers in first person view.  The placement system is also bright and kinda distracting.  The weird thing is that you also see what other players are "planning" to build.  It makes for easy communication when building the path way but sometimes you get your build tool mixed up with your allies build tools.  At least the upside on that is if you misplace your wall/tower you can always sell it for all of your resources back.Besides the issues which I would consider pretty minor, I would rate this game extremely playable and worth the purchase.  Tower defense games are naturally addicting but then you add in FPS too it?  Well I'm sold!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												As a fan of the original Sanctum, playing this game can feel a little weird. Firstly, you're far more limited on towers, with you starting off only being able to deploy/upgrade 1 kind of tower and can get a max of 4 as you progress. You also only have 2 weapons. Before you had a giant blank canvas to develop into a maze of towers with your core WAY off at the end, now your core is almost in the middle of things. So if you've developed tactics from the first game, they won;t fly in this one. Instead of a ton of towers, you're better off with a few that get a lot of upgrades. And instead of only really needing to shoot a few special enemies, now you're gonna be in the thick of it, so pick your weapons carefully.Honetly, from what I've seen this game takes Sanctum in a direction that it seemed to be heading for anyway. The first was almsot all about tower placement and maze formation, while this game gives the FPS elements more of the spotlight. The two work well together despite what you'd think, and it adds a level of tactical gameplay with the limiting of towers and weapons not to mention character selection since each has their own signiture weapon and defauly bonuses.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												8/10A great concept, FPS meets tower defense, in up to four player co-op going against hoards of aliens trying to destroy your precious white orbs that float in the corner. The artistic style in this game is unmatched, particuarly the future city levels, and the comic book style taken between levels. A major advancement of the first, it offers four playable characters, and a fifth DLC, along with a hoast of different map sizes, layouts and routines to challenge even the most competitive and prepared teams.The level of strategy comes from the types of towers that are placed in the arena, As you level up your character, you unlock new weapons and towers, with each one being more or less useful against the dozen or so different types of enemies. There are a number of modes, but the best action comes from the frantic end stage bosses that leave teams struggling to survive and defend the last of their resources.The reload mechanic is odd, with no actual ammo being required, rather you just wait or change weapon for stock to reload. Careful balance of shooting, dodging and tower preparation and location are crucial to survival. A truely unique, enjoyable tower defense game.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												You can be a little girl that goes flying from the recoil of a rocket launcher. 10/10 for real physics.Simply put... It's like playing some of those really great Warcraft 3 mazing tower defense games, where you build your towers to maze and fight enemies wave after wave. Instead of merely watching your towers though, you can join in, like any smart builder would do, using one of four (five is DLC (I THINK)) characters, and a choice of weapons, towers and perks, you can frankly, change the output of any game by pulling aggro (bit sorry for the MMO term).There's a bunch of easter eggs ingame, and there's a butt load of fun to be had by parkouring your way out of the maps, or in Bio Lab's case, merely dropping through a hole, next to a Gandalf easter egg. Just, try not to get mad if you're online and didn't discuss the mazing technique to be done.Oh and, if you do use the rocket launcher, try not to commit suicide. You really underestimate how far the closest cliff actually is sometimes.

												At first I did not want to buy this game, the screenshots didnt look very promising. But then I got convinced by a friend and started playing it --- it's incredibly awesome, a must have for a tower defense fan like me.It combines:- tactical towerdefense with a lot of different and interesting towers, each one you can upgrade 3 times and then overcharge them, so they get even more powerful- a kind of ego shooter to support your towers and a lot of possibilities to increase your strategy- many different monsters with abilities and weak spots, making every one of them a challenge and worthy opponent- a lot of hours of fun playing due to a long campaign and currently 4 addons, also a survival mode and hardcore-options- multiplayer fun with up to 4 playersI just can recommend this game to everyone who loves strategy and tower defense.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2013
												While Sanctum 2 is a good game, I think the original is better. If you enjoyed the original, the sequel is worth playing. But if youre new to Sanctum, start with the first game, especially if you plan to play alone. There have been several changes to gameplay mechanics, a couple of which are improvements. Some enemies will attack the player instead of just running to the core, and bosses can destroy towers. If you cant afford to fully upgrade a tower you can partially upgrade for a small stat boost. But other changes are restrictive. You can only build 15 towers per map. There are no mid game checkpoints - fail and its back to wave 1. Loadouts are smaller (2 weapons and 4 towers compared to 3 and 6 previously) which means that you cant fully appreciate the tactical depth unless you play with a coop partner who brings different gear. A new range of perks have been added, but the ability to upgrade guns has been removed, and many weapons/towers/perks are locked until you grind enough XP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												The Sanctum series really set the standards of FPS-Tower Defense hybrid. However, Sanctum 2 is very much different than the first Sanctum. While Sanctum is 90% tower defense and 10% hero defense, Sanctum 2 is 50% tower defense and 50% hero defense. This means you can't just build-and-forget like the first Sanctum, where you just have to have enough decent towers and a well-made maze and you'll make it through the waves.In Sanctum 2, you'll have to fire your guns just as often as your towers or you'll lose the wave. This makes for a more immersive game which requires more input and interaction from players, and proper strategies will determine the border between victory or annihilation. Not to mention you can get killed if the wave mobs get close to you.Add a little RPG element to the mix where you get to select a character, equip his/her weapons, select your towers and skills obtained by leveling up, and you have yourself a semi-complex game that will keep you occupied for many hours and offers high replayability value.Pick up a bunch of friends and buy the pack for this game, and you can't go wrong. Most definitely recommended, better than a lot of games currently in the market, and it is very affordable and worth the money.Without a doubt, 8 out of 10.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I have mixed feelings about this game. I still recommend you buy it, especially if you played the first game, but let's go over a few new details. In Sanctum 1, it was all about the towers and a lovely first person tower defense game...however, in Sanctum 2 there are tons of changes from the first game that make it more of a challenge and overall different feel compared to the first game. You get a limit on how many towers can place, they cost more, they are harder to upgrade, and it relies on you to kill most of the enemies with the towers as support instead of vice versa from the original game. To me, I had to rethink and form almost completely new strategies for this game. That being said, it is still a fantastic, albeit difficult, game. The maps are all new with beautiful design to them, and many of which can allow you to go back and play them again by creating a new path they may be better than your original to lead the Lumes (enemies) through. The towers in this game are familiar with the first one with a couple of new editions. Also there are 4 characters you can play as and customize with various perks, weapons, and towers for endless possibilities strategically. Some maps are more difficult than others and will frustrate you as they did me. Sometimes I'm led to believe this game was meant to be played with others through co-op in order to beat the levels, but then I find a new plan that works and even though it may be hard, you can solo this game should you wish. Overall, I give this game a solid 8 out of 10 if I had to, and I recommend it to those of you who love real time strategy, FPS, and/or tower defense games. This game just has it all wrapped into one. Also, I strongly recommend it to those of you who are in need of a game outside of TF2 and looking for another great multiplayer game you can play together and have some fun. The single-player side is great--don't misunderstand--, but that feeling of success when shared with friends after beating a level makes it oh-so-much-more satisfying.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												Bought this game on a sale - 40 hours later I'm wondering where my time has gone by.This is a very active FPS tower defense game. You have a vast choice of towers which are effective against various ennemies  and therefore suit different strategies. You can instantly check how effective they actually are in terms of total damage, damage during the last mob round, etc. You are also able to re-arrange and replace them if necessary ; but on a higher level this would result in a money penalty, therefore prompting you to think well ahead. The various classes add great variety as each of them have their own strengths. Fear not if you worry about your aim: there is a mad rocket launcher girl. Just shoot away and blow stuff up.Over time you gain experience and levels which unlock new towers, new weapons and new stat effects. They become extremely relevant once you play with other people. Do you prefer a passive support role or would you rather be a living killing machine with infinite respawns? The choice is up to you. The multiplayer is defintely a lot of fun ; and the community has been surprinsingly NICE. Maybe the text to speech ability encourages others to be friendly? The setups are pretty simple: you can either play your campaign on your own or allow other players to join you. While you have no control over who joins you, you're able to kick/ban players if necessary. Loot is always fairly distributed which allows everyone to participate actively in reinforcing your defences. The gameplay is definitely top-notch. Consequently you actually don't even pay attention to other facts - such as surprinsingly good graphics and music. I had no lag / spike issues either during my online campaign. The game goes even beyond being a FPS TD game by pushing the player to explore its maps in order to find easter eggs, secret areas and even playable arcade games. That's pretty unique - and also rewarded through achievements! To be honest I'm only annoyed by the fact that you need all the DLCs in oder to get 100% achievements. I'll wait for a sale, but so far the game has been fantastic.Edit: Recently got the Season Pass - and it's amazing! The DLCs provide awesome content in terms of story, maps, new ennemies, etc. Fantastic. :-)

content:
Posted: June 8, 2013
												It is impossible to deny that Coffee Stain Studios took just about everything good in Sanctum and amped it up tenfold for Sanctum 2. Enhancing the coop mode by adding three new player characters alongside the original protagonist, each specializing in one of four weapon categories (Assault Rifles, Snipers, Shotguns and a big happy rocket launcher that blinds the entire right side of your screen).Like the previous title, Sanctum 2 is a fast-paced FPS tower defense game that requires a heavy load of brainpower to keep the waves of alien enemies away from your core. In Sanctum 2 the challenge level is increased, giving the player less resources after each wave and removing the ability to upgrade weapons with resources, forcing the player to focus less on weapon damage and instead on carefully placed towers, walls and turrets to keep the enemy waves back, as well as the addition of a timer to mix things up and make the waves more chaotic. With an immersive campaign mode playable in both single player or coop, Sanctum 2 offers mind-blowing gameplay complimented with a level-up system that rewards the player with unlockable towers, weapons and perks as well as a digital comic that offers insight into Sanctum's world which reveals a page or two before every stage. Sanctum 2 is a direct upgrade to Sanctum, and is well worth the time for any fans of the original.

												Underrated game. I think this game would have a lot of potential to hold a strong userbase if they had focused on more multiplayer things, like ramping up the difficulty in ways other than hp or maybe something like a vs mode.If you like tower defense you'll like this game. content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I have mixed feelings about this game. I still recommend you buy it, especially if you played the first game, but let's go over a few new details. In Sanctum 1, it was all about the towers and a lovely first person tower defense game...however, in Sanctum 2 there are tons of changes from the first game that make it more of a challenge and overall different feel compared to the first game. You get a limit on how many towers can place, they cost more, they are harder to upgrade, and it relies on you to kill most of the enemies with the towers as support instead of vice versa from the original game. To me, I had to rethink and form almost completely new strategies for this game. That being said, it is still a fantastic, albeit difficult, game. The maps are all new with beautiful design to them, and many of which can allow you to go back and play them again by creating a new path they may be better than your original to lead the Lumes (enemies) through. The towers in this game are familiar with the first one with a couple of new editions. Also there are 4 characters you can play as and customize with various perks, weapons, and towers for endless possibilities strategically. Some maps are more difficult than others and will frustrate you as they did me. Sometimes I'm led to believe this game was meant to be played with others through co-op in order to beat the levels, but then I find a new plan that works and even though it may be hard, you can solo this game should you wish. Overall, I give this game a solid 8 out of 10 if I had to, and I recommend it to those of you who love real time strategy, FPS, and/or tower defense games. This game just has it all wrapped into one. Also, I strongly recommend it to those of you who are in need of a game outside of TF2 and looking for another great multiplayer game you can play together and have some fun. The single-player side is great--don't misunderstand--, but that feeling of success when shared with friends after beating a level makes it oh-so-much-more satisfying.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												So the premise of this game is that humans have established colonies in the skies over an alien planet. They use magical blue balls of light (cores) to convert the gasses present into oxygen and kill the native spores. The problem is that the planet is already occupied by an alien race of highly evolved mushrooms. The mushroom people under the direction of unknown telepathic boss entity whom you never fight create giant organic shafts to the colonies to try to murder them dead.In the game you will create a maze of towers in an attempt to halt the advance of the mushroom people before they destroy you're magical blue ball as is typical of a Tower Defense game. you will spend 5, 10 or 15 minutes per level depositing towers that will ultimately only do about thirty percent of the damage necessary to kill the enemy waves. The rest is up to you. You can choose two of a plethora of weapons to aid you in the struggle. The game does not address why a gun held by a five foot two to six foot tall human out damages half dozen tool shed sized tower mounted guns you drop and arguably that means this game isn't really a TD. There are "perks" you can select to improve you're characters/towers performance but there’s really nothing that will turn this game into an actual Tower Defense, which is unfortunate.The longer you play the game the more powerful guns, perks and towers you can unlock, particularly if you buy the DLC. I'm sure we all know the DLC drill by now. For an extra five dollars you will get access to all the content that was cut from the game during the alpha and beta tests for quality control and balance reasons. Ideally that content has since been fixed/balanced/polished but we never know until we shell out the cash. To their credit the DLC for Sanctum 2 does provide a lot of interesting content. The towers, perks and maps it adds do a great deal to increase replayability of the game and it rounds out the base games story that ends on a cliffhanger.The real strength of this game is the level design. Like every other piece of science fiction made in the past twelve years almost everything looks like an Ipod that said this game does it particularly well. The integration of organic vines and spores growing over the utopian surfaces/structures in this game are very imaginative and well done. A lot of games (Doom 3/Dead Space) place a strong aesthetic emphasis in a human environment being reverse terraformed by some perverse alien influence but truthfully Sanctum 2 does it better. The levels are distinct from each other in groups as you proceed from an idealistic lived in colony under attack to the deteriorating front lines to an industrial themed colony abandoned some years or generations earlier. The theme is that the further into the game you go the closer to the planet you get until ultimately you are beneath its surface in a giant cavern with mushroom Jesus. In the tradition of classic FPS games there are many many secret areas and players are rewarded for their diligent exploration. Ironically the maps are far bigger in scope then the developers were prepared to work with and you’ll shudder when you realize that you can’t incorporate some of the games incredibly ideal choke points into you’re defense as they are simply too far away from where the action will be…. If they allowed you to place your own cores the quality of the game would quadruple immediately but thats something they will have to consider for a sequel.The biggest issue with the game is the many many clipping errors. This game will kill you or force you to consul command suicide many times as you fall through solid objects or get stuck between them. In the basic game it doesn’t matter very much as you can wait out the 9 second respawn time once or twice and it isn’t likely to lose the game for you. Tragically the developers compounded this issue by encouraging the players to play with “five feats of strength” on to create a more challenging experience… One of these “feats” is a no respawn mode…  So basically each time you die to a developer error, which will be once or twice a game, you’ll also lose the level. Since playing with the feats of strength on is going to be your last real experience with the game they are brutally poisoning their consumer base who will only remember losing 30 minutes of an expertly played game because Coffe Stain Studio's didn’t properly patch or beta test. Hardcore modes are made for polished games made by hardcore developers. It might be a tough pill for Coffee Stain Studios to swallow but they just haven’t reached that point yet.For ten dollars it is a really cool indie game. The maps if not always utilized ideally are a clever visual spectacle and it does have a lot of replay value. If Coffee Stain Studio focuses on adding general content to their games and take their player testers a little more seriously these guys could easily be around for another few years. Otherwise they'll find themselves doing the 3d effects for their regional weather channels talking about once whens.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I held off writing this review until all the DLC came out because as is the case with many games nowadays community feedback and devoted developers often cause games to undergo big changes even after release, and this game is no exception. Many of the problems people had with the game when it came out are gone, and as a full package with all 4 DLC the game is fully realized and certainly worth your time and money.This game is in a weird spot. If you're a shooter fan, it may feel like a fairly competent shooter, with some other weird turret things thrown in. If you're a Tower Defense player, it will feel very strange not always having a bird's eye veiw mainscreen (though there is a minimap and pressing a button will enlarge it so don't worry) and having these wierd variables of teammates and not having perfect aim all the time. If you like both, it is an outstanding blend of the two genres. And I recommend it to both fps and td fans. Fans of both sides may be dissapointed in the lack of this or that, but if you forget about games you've already played to compare it to for a minute, those things may not make sense in this hybrid.That being said, the gameplay is phenomenal. A great blend of strategy and skill, but without requiring too many desicions and responsibilities that the player can easily become to overwhelmed. You build a maze, build towers (you choose what to bring beforehand) and then get to shooting. Mistakes are punished but don't mean the end until very late in the game. You have many ways to fix your holes and mistakes, even mid-wave. There is also an immense amount of freedom. Pro FPS-er? Take a bunch of perks that help you kill enemies and just let the towers clean up. TD Vet? Create a build that buffs your towers so you don't need to do much shooting. There's loads of combinations and styles of play that make the replay value even bigger. There's always that weird combo you want to try out for fun just to see if you can beat the level with it. The levels curve in very nicely, and there are enough modes and difficulty modifyers to keep you playing well after you've reached max level. Speaking of which, there's also a level up system where you unlock new weapons and perks. Early unlocks tend to be more general and easy to use, while still being powerful in their own right. Later unlocks are more specialized and require a bit more skill and familiarity with the game, and offer a slight better advantage if used correctly. No one unlock completely invalidates another, either. It's a very good system.In addition, the single player and multiplayer are vastly different experiences. Play both. They're the exact same game but as soon as you have a team, its an almost completely different one. The way multiplayer and singleplayer seamlessly blend together is great as well, and usually only requires you to shift mindsets, not builds (at least in the middle of a map - organizing for the next one and specializing is one of the myriad ways the game becomes different). The outstanding team at Coffeestain is one of the most hardworking and talented development teams I've seen from an indie studio in a long time. I often find myself drawing parallels between them and CDProjekt Red when they started out. You can see the level of attention to detail if you look at the game closely, how every little piece seems to sort of mesh together to make a very nice whole. The art and music direction is phenomenal, without saying anything and before the first wave even starts you get a feel for it, where you are, what you're doing, and the impact you're having. The comic book for loading screens just gives the right amount of context to understand what's going on, the environments, music, and enemies tell the real story.The game isn't without its flaws though. Sometimes it can lag a little bit or disconnect you, but that could just be my bad internet. Many guns don't feel terribly satisfying to shoot because things don't have so much health, and many of the enemies look similar. It's hard to find to many criticisms for the game though.Overall, I highly recommend you pick up the whole package. It isn't for everyone, I will concede, so I also recommend trying the demo and see how you like the first few levels. Then pick up the whole game and if you want to the season pass or individual DLCs. They're all fantastic additions to the game. One even includes a fifth playable character. Don't worry if your friends aren't getting it and you think you'll have no one to play with, the community here is also one of the friendliest I've ever encountered.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												TL;DR: Massive improvement over Sanctum 1. Leveling system doesn't feel grindy, and helps to introduce old and new sanctum players into the new towers and features. Multiplayer can be annoying sometimes with trolls public play, but overall the community is helpful and welcoming. Playing with friends is very rewarding and fun.Let's start from the top. If it is not obvious already, Sanctum 2 is the sequel to Sanctum, the Unreal Engine-based game that came on the scene slow at first before it made a big breakout on Steam, prompting this sequel.First impressions from a Sanctum 1 player: WOW, this game has fixed a lot of gameplay annoyances that the first Sanctum had. Sanctum 2 has trashed the high, inaccessible walls of its predecessor with more sensible barriers that the player can actually mantle. Also, towers can now be partially upgraded in between the proper "levels" so no more sitting on 99 credits that can't do anything because you are one short of the upgrade. All of your towers maxed out? You can now OVERCHARGE them with excess money, with diminishing returns of course.Next up, the UI. Another massive improvement. Sanctum 1 didn't really give great descriptions of each tower, and the stats of towers were not as easy to read, so knowing the proper abilities of a tower (essential for a Tower Defense game) couldn't be done at a glance. Now, a simple mouse over on the tower tells the player everything they need to know, and range is displayed in a helpful holographic overlay.Now, the new progression system, at first it may trigger the eyeroll of shoving grindy RPG elements where they don't belong, but the implementation is solid. The player isn't hamstrung from completing levels due to being a lower level. Grinding simply doesn't happen, in the since that you don't find yourself needing to repeat levels endlessly. You can however, enable "Feats of Strength" when you replay old levels to substantially increase difficulty (and your XP reward) if you find yourself wanting to level faster. Being low level also doesn't exclude you from playing with higher level players. Because each player is limited to a certain number of tower and perk slots, you can always find a niche to fill in multiplayer (I enjoy playing the rocket launcher character and managing airborne minions).Overall, I can't see a reason not to get this game if you enjoy Tower Defense or Action Shooters for that matter. Sanctum offers short, replayable fun for a very low price. Buy this game!

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												I have mixed feelings about this game.While the gameplay is incredible, the difficulty is too high to maintain in early stages. You often lack the basic resources to have a small chance at defeating the massive hordes of enemies. While this is not a initially bad thing, as it is a TD/FPS hybrid, it stays that way throughout the entire mission. Difficulty does not seem to scale with the lack of players you have.The tutorial is one of the worst I have seen, giving very little information about how to play the game or what anything on screen means.I can't say much about the story, as I haven't played the original.The characters/weapons are okay at best. The only one I truly enjoyed playing was the sniper robot, because it is the most diverse. The Squad Leader character's weapon has too much recoil to be worth the shot (thank you, thank you, I'll be here all night).TL;DRSanctum 2: Yet another reason we need a in-between review button.

content:
Posted: January 23
												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing trash. Sanctum 1 felt a little underdone, but at least it was a fun tower defense with fps elements. Sanctum 2 is an atrocity and isn't the same game in any way. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ wave survival FPS that happens to have a couple towers.Remember those giant mazes you constructed in sanctum 1? Say hello to a 15 tower limit. Playing with friends? SAME 15 TOWER LIMIT. Have fun dividing those up.Remember that effective and useful overhead map? ♥♥♥♥ you, that's right outta here.Remember televators making it easy to move around the map? Haha, yea ♥♥♥♥ing right. Remember upgrading your weapons? Nope. That's gone.Remember how your used to be able to craft a path with your towers? SAY HELLO TO BOSS UNITS, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. They'll kick stomp right through your♥♥♥♥♥♥and go straight for the core. Because ♥♥♥♥ you, that's why.Oh, but you can turn on sandbox mode and place all the towers you want. But it's unranked, you don't level up and you won't ever unlock anything. So enjoy placing your 1 tower over and over again. The devs claim this has to do with resource utilization. It hurts my brain to think they can't run more than 15 towers and a handful or NPCs when the first one could run dozens on older tech.Any the game will start before all players have joined and readied up, meaning some players can miss the first wave entirely. And, and base tower blocks are now a separate resource and are randomly and unevenly distributed to players. Wave 1: Player 1 gets 0 base block points, Player 2 gets 10. Have fun.And despite all that, they still have the nerve to charge for multiple overpriced DLC packs. Want a powerful weapon or tower? Pay up, ♥♥♥♥♥es.Coffee Stain took Sanctum 1, which had some fun and relatively unique mechanics, and tossed it in a blender with some feces and broken code and then took a big ol' sanctum steamer right on our chests. This game is worse than Sanctum 1 in every conceivable way. Do not buy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Sanctum 2 is an excellent game, and in my own opinion, better than the first, a rarity in the gaming industry. Players of the original Sanctum will find that it has a similar feel to the original, but the small things take a lot of getting used to, for example the UI is packed with more information than before on a different location of the screen. Initially because of this, I found the game difficult to play, but after playing a few levels the interface was fairly easy to read from and playing was comfortable. The levels themselves are colossal, full of secrets, and both graphically and aesthetically pleasing. The game is well optimised, as shown by my less-than-stellar PC being able to handle this game fairly well with some graphical options turned off. The gameplay feels like a less-flamboyant Borderlands, which suits the aesthetic of the game well. The game does have it's bugs. I, on more than one occasion have found myself wedged between two slanted sections of wall and getting stuck. The game does have a suicide button for this purpose, but during a wave it can be irritating dealing with the 10-second respawn time as the enemy skips merrily towards the core. I have encountered crash bugs, although I suspect they're my PC's fault.I heartily reccomend Sanctum 2, and by extension, it's predecessor Sanctum. Sanctum 2 is certainly one of my top-5 games of all time and you should certainly buy it if you think it'd be your thing.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												EDIT: While the below review still holds true for the most part, after having played the game more, I've come to the conclusion that Sanctum 2 has much more of a learning curve than Sanctum. Sanctum is pretty easy to just jump into and enjoy, while Sanctum 2 requires you to learn how to really play the game and get some specific upgrades before it starts being really good. However, once you get to that point, it is a great experience possibly even better than the first despite the shortcomings.I give this a thumbs up overall because it is still a fun game; the blending of FPS and tower defense that is Sanctum is here, the maze-making strategy is here, and the multiplayer is better and more worthwhile than before. There are some good new features, but as a fan who loved and played a lot of the first, I am disappointed with a lot of the things they did here. But I'll start with the good:Multiple characters to choose from adds a new element of strategy, and equipping appropriate perks adds further. As all bonuses that can theoretically stack together do, equipping each character with appropriate perks for the best results is a welcome addition to the franchise that allows players to experiment for the combos that best suit them.Maps are much better designed than in the first Sanctum with much more attention to detail and more thought in strategic use of the environment. The campaign and leveling system are also a welcome addition, giving a feeling of progress, though some unlocks may take a bit too long to unlock. Lastly, there's a wider range of guns and towers available to choose from.It also looks really nice graphically.But now, the disappointments. I know this is a new game and shouldn't just be compared to the first, but as this is a sequel, things should get better, not worse, and a comparison will be necessary to make my point.Most of my issues can be summed up as such: the maps may be bigger, but the game feels so much smaller. Customization was supposed to be an important upgrade from Sanctum to Sanctum 2, but I honestly feel like the first had better customization. Number of guns allowed to each player has been reduced from 3 to 2, with 1 of those being locked to the character until capping your level, meaning only one weapon can actually be chosen for any given character, AND they can no longer be upgraded. Yet despite this, the game is actually more FPS-centric due to the limits on blocks and towers, as even without any feats of strength activated one can't really get away with just towers, again unlike the first, making for fewer different ways to actually play the game.Number of towers brought to a map maxes out at 4 per player, down from the 6 of the original. Additionally, floors are gone completely and Holo tower and Televators have also left the building, leaving basically only the two slowing towers to support the FPS aspect at all, and no guns which do the reverse (Freeze is gone), severing that integration completely aside from a few perks. Also, towers can only be upgraded to level 3 instead of 6, after which they go into "overcharge," which is just throwing as many extra resources as you want at it to make it more continually more powerful, and I guess is basically the same thing.Blocks - now tower bases - are limited and given out per wave instead of costing a small amount of resources, preventing players from really building a maze until the map is over, seeing as maps are not longer than 10 waves, which was the shortest in the previous game, where it went as high as 30 in standard mode. Additionally, only 15 towers can actually be built per map, and the base cost of them has increased as much as 10x, no exaggeration; base Gatling now costs 100 instead of 10, and resources given hasn't increased to compensate (if anything it's lower). I guess as compensation upgrade costs don't increase as you continue to upgrade, but it doesn't matter much since they only go to level 3 and then overcharge anyway.What's the point of the maps being so big if I can only realistically use small portions of them?Good multiplayer is definitely not a bad thing in my book, but the game kind of shafts solo players. Many maps have multiple entry points for the enemies, occasionally in ways that prevent the two sides from ever joining before the core (and some have two cores), requiring a solo player to juggle two sides, a problem compounded further by the limitations to blocks and towers. A few of these maps existing would be fine, but not as many as there are here, especially since televators are no longer around to allow the player to move around quickly.The game is definitely a better multiplayer experience than single. It can be played single player, but it will be frustrating at times. Best to get a friend or two in on the action. Again, still a good game overall. If you liked Sanctum but thought it needed some improving, this might be for you. If you liked a lot of things in Sanctum, give it a shot, but be careful.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Sanctum 2 is a great follow-up to Sanctum 1. It's a tower defense, FPS, action, strategy Co-op game, based on defending the core from lumes, alien invaders trying to destroy the planet.Sanctum 2 is, yes, a online game. You can make your world online, so that other players can join, or private, so that it is just you. There are 4 worlds, not counting the DLC worlds. There is a campaign to the game, but I don't really know how to explain it. The game is great for playing with friends, and I really enjoy this game. The DLC for the game, uncover the rest of the story, since the end of the game left players at a cliff hanger. Some of the achivements in the game can only be unlocked by getting AND playing them. The main strategy is to maze the level, and place down as many "attack towers" down as possible.Overall, this is a fantasic game. I really like it, and it was one of the first games, (besides Borderlands 2), on Steam that I ever played. I recommend this game to everyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This is NOT Sanctum 1. If you are going into this expecting it to be exactly like the first, then be forewarned that it is not. Also, in this review, I am including all DLC in my considerations, and I am including into consideration what this game has set out to be rather than what I personally expect from a TD or FPS game.That having been said to appease the die hard purists of the original and the two genres, this game is on it's own merrit absolutely awesome. It has it's highs and lows like most any game, although there are a lot more highs than there are lows. There is a little bit of pacing and balance issues when it comes to playing straight through as you will inevitably hit a point where you are forced to improve not only your skill but also your choice of armaments or when certain armaments or combinations that are just completely overkill for the level you are facing. With sufficient skill and sufficient experience with the different combos, there is no reason you can't make almost any combination work, but getting to that skill point will take a bit of time and some trial and error that you just wont nail down on your first play through or until you've played enough to cap out you levels. On the higher difficulty levels though, that skill and knowing the combinations is critical and on the hardest difficulty for the most part you will need to bring your A game and the best combos you can muster. That is all part of what makes a good TD game though; possibilities and choices in how you play, replayability without getting stale fast, and the flexibility of different difficulties that includes something for the casual to the hardcore.The FPS element does feel light, and the TD element does feel somewhat simplified when compared to their pure counterparts, but the state of both is perfect for the sake of trying to play both at once without getting overwhelmed as a new player and in order to prevent requiring days of number crunching or rote memorization of patterns. At some point though, you will beat everything and then it will boil down to just survival mode and how many waves can you kill before it's impossible. When you get to that point after playing for many many hours, it will inevitably get pretty dull for most.All in all, just considering Sanctum 2 and only the scope of the game, I would give it a 80/85 in terms of what it set out to do and how well it delivers (points docked due to lack of really long term replayability for completionists, and minor pacing/balance issues). I would give it a 80/100 when comparing it against all other games I've ever played of all genres.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												This game and the orignal are two of the most fantastic multiplayer Tower Defense games i've ever played. Sanctum 2 gives you great growth over time as you unlock new towers and guns through leveling. While the single player is fun and immersive, the multiplayer aspect is where Sanctum 2 shines above other Tower Defense games. With aliens that are combative against the player, it's not just your towers or core taking damage, it adds aspects of FPS perspectives to a tradional TD. Being a moving target also changes how tower placement can be managed. the game is well thought out and the storyline is interesting. Whether you're looking for a fun game to LAN, or a game to kill some time at a good pace, Sanctum 2 is a diverse and exciting game.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Sanctum 2, in my opinion, surpasses Sanctum 1 in many ways. First off, the levelling system. Although people may dislike the fact that you have to unlock the towers that you at access to right from the get-go in Sanctum 1 in Sanctum 2, I think it gives more incentive to certain aspects of Sanctum 1 which I think needed it. For example, in Sanctum 1, Survival Mode felt like it was a bit lacking in motivation for me, whilst in Sanctum 2, I was heavily motivated to try my hardest at all times during survival because I knew that the longer I survived, the more experience points I would get. The Second improvement would be the sheer amount of content this game has! Sanctum 2 has about twice as many maps to play through than Sanctum 1 and many new enemies to learn about! Thirdly, the controls gained a major improvement. In Sanctum 2 the controls are more FPS-like than ever before! If enjoyed how Borderlands 2 controls, you will like how Sanctum 2 controls. There are also many core gameplay elements tweaked in Sanctum 2. The biggest example of change is in the Combat Phase, which requires much more input from the player in skill. Another example of improvement is the new upgrading system. Each tower now only has 3 tiers and upgrading is investment based! So even if you don't have enough resources to upgrade a tower to the next tier, you can still invest in it to boost its stats slightly. You can even invest after the tower reaches its maximum tier. Doing this will result in you "overcharging" the tower, which will boost a prominent stat or some prominent stats (eg. Damage, Range, etc) even further! The last improvement is with the graphics. This game looks gorgeous and compared to Sanctum 1 is the equivilent of today's FPS graphics. This game is a 100% "WIN" in my book and you should buy it right now.
