content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												I didn't care for the multi-player focus of this game compared to the first one. There's no true "single player" option. You have to start a match then set it to private or people can just join your game whenever. And since you're always considered to be in an "online" match you CAN'T PAUSE THE GAME! There's no teleports and the levels are much larger, so you really can't be everywhere you need to be with just one person. The towers are much stronger, but you're only given enough resources to build 4 to 5 towers in a level, which means the players have to pick up the slack, which is again a problem with only one player.I have absolutely zero interest in playing games with other random people because SO MANY PEOPLE ARE BAD AT GAMES!!! It's always a frustrating experience every time I try it.The campaign can be completed solo because I've done it. But the entire game was frustrating because so many levels were obviously designed with more than one person in mind.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Quick summary: More FPS, Less TD, now it feels like another FPS with a gimmick.Original Sanctum offered a nice blend of Tower Defence and First Person Shooter, where carefully planned blocks and tower layout was crucial to completing higher waves and individual skills as a shooter certainly contributing to keep the enemy mob under control. Sanctum 2 however seem to have watered down the strategy part and heavily leaned towards the FPS orientated game by applying constraints to the towers you can build.In the original Sanctum, the aim of the game was in-line with the Tower Defence genre, building up your defence as much as your resource allows until you're overwhelmed by the enemy or until you ride out the wave. Sanctum 2 has made three major changes from the predecessor;1.  blocks and towers now have separate resource pools2. there is a limitation on the number of towers you can have built at anytime.3. no more weapon upgrades.The above changes diminishes the reward for carefully thought out, long-term planning and favour on-the-fly, impulsive decisions. With blocks, towers and weapons not sharing tje resource pool, there are no more dilemmas regarding the early game. There used to be a choice on how to begin the game. Should I start building the maze early?, Add more towers and supports? or perhaps upgrade your own weapon and take responsibility for the enemy to come? you had a choice. Now the guns you picked cannot have custom upgrades, you can build only certain amount of blocks per wave and have a pitiful amount to build maybe couple of towers. There really is not much you can do different. This also affect the mid-game where you are left with more blocks than you need with no resource to upgrade your tower. For a tower defence game where resource management is the key, it seems so wasteful.The changes also shorten the length of the game. No weapon upgrade, limit on tower number and reduced resource for tower upgrades means the game cannot grow out for too long. In tower defence games it is a battle between how much and how fast you build your defence against how tough the enemies grow. Cripple the player's ability to upgrade and it is obvious that the waves count has to be reduced. To compensate and "up the difficulty", the big boss monster will walk straight through the maze you built, smashing away the beautiful defence you have planned and built. No tower defence for that part, just shoot.For Multiplayer, Sanctum 2 has introduced player levels with towers, weapons and even the tower slots using the "unlock at this level" mechanism. At first it may seem that this may encourage players of equal progression to play together but it significantly reduces the amount a new player can contribute to the game. A new player would have to do a little grind before joining a match.With that said, Sanctum 2 brought few nice ideas into the game.Player Classes encourages the players to work as a team, each taking on a particular role to play. the idea is nice although some role may feel left out when their speciality is not required or ill fitted for the job at hand. The original allowed for 3 weapons, which gave a little more freedom and perhaps better backup weapon would have been nice. Sniper class especially can be frustrating when the team requires fire rate than firepower and even worse if you are fighting alone.Sanctum 2 have lowered platforms and hostile enemies. This is one thing I actually commend and it feels like an improvement. In the original Sanctum, the enemies simply followed the shortest path to the core and players couldnt really be killed unless you stood in front of them. This time, the blocks are lowered in height and some of the monsters will actually chase you and attack you. It adds bit more action to the game without destroying the strategy of Tower Defence. No more of being lazy, letting towers do the work and watching the action as the overlord; you gotta get down there and contribute.In conclusion Sanctum 2 feels like it has deviated away from the planned, strategy cored gameplay that made it so unique and interesting. The higher dosage of FPS was welcomed but to sacrifice the TD element for it is highly questionable in my opinion. Perhaps for those who prefer more shooting this maybe more enjoyable. But for me who enjoyed  the careful planning of the Lumen killing floor, can't help but compare it to the original Sanctum. The boundless possibilities of building your own defence was what I was after and I feel rather disappointed by the lack there of.

												Sanctum 2 is the huge let down of my gaming list. After enjoying so much the first game, I was looking forward to prolong the experience. However, significant changes in the game core design completely altered my in-game happiness. Somehow, it feels more like a FPS than a tower defense. Restriction to build towers, shared resources, and overwhelming graphical effects were not the improvements I was looking for. It is a different game with which I did not fall in love. Maybe you will.

content:

												Sanctum 1 included some pretty cool concepts. FPS tower defense? Hell yes. Everything about the game was perfect. The FPS aspect, admittedly was a tiny bit half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ But it did play an important role against some enemies.Sanctum 2 however ♥♥♥♥♥ all over the first game, by overemphasizing the FPS aspect, leaving the tower defense aspect in the dust. While leaving weapons about as weak as they used to be, you're lucky to kill 1, MAYBE 2 enemies tops before you're forced to reload (And reloading takes about 5~ seconds) Towers are far too weak, far too expensive to build and far too expensive to upgrade. Other than walls to block the enemy, there is literally no point in building a single tower because they don't provide much help.There also a larger emphasis on the co-op aspect, which hurts the single player experience considerably.Over-all, this game is just a terrible game. Take a pass on it.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												This game - contrary to it's prequel - is more a shooter than a tower defense game. While you can still build mazes the fact that your tower capacity is limited to a maximum of 15 towers IN TOTAL per map does not leave room for trying out neat combinations. Coupled with the fact that more often than not you're presented with 2 separate enemy-paths forcing you to spread your build and focus out and leaving you with just enough income after a wave to place one new or upgrade one already placed tower. The enemy variety is ok even though there are numerous enemies that your towers won't be able to deal with due to "immune everywhere but red spot" mechanics force the player to chase around big baddies at least a couple of times per map. The climax are the "boss" enemies that you face. In the last couple of maps I played i faced at least one boss per map. They spawn and... just smash your towers. They walk up to them and smash them or shoot lazers at them destroying your laid-out maze opening paths for the hords of enemis to simply bypass your defences making you deal with everything on your own. After this happened thrice to me I quit the game and just deinstalled it. It my be fun in co-op but i've lost interest before trying it out. In my opinion, just get the first game and ignore this, unless you want a horde-coop shooter with maze building elements. I liked the first Sanctum but this game was more frustration than fun.

number of helpful: 10 of 23 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												I have taken it upon myself to fill in some of the blanks in this Game's pock-marked plot:Aliens are attacking (I'll assume it's a political ideological disagreement that has exhausted all efforts at diplomacy), and, to add insult to injury, the incompetent city planner responsible for the outrageously poor placement of the Energy Cores (of apocryphal importance) also ran up a considerable amount of debt, so a reliable team of two sisters, a random dude and a sniper-robot must fend off these Alien saboteurs on a very tight budget. Despite the state of war, it is expected that you play fair. Although it would be more efficient to build a 50ft wall with hundreds of maxed out turrets everywhere, it wouldn't be fair to the aliens, who request that you leave at the very least, a pathway one metre wide from their entrance all the way to the Energy Core. In return, the aliens have shown the decency to wait until your walls are set up before they attack in waves that gradually increase in speed, power, and numbers. The aliens will stop at nothing to destroy the Core, until you stop them once, then they give up and move to a different undefended core in a different terrain. This game attempts to be a fusion between the genres of First Person Shooter and Tower Defense, but the addition of Tower Defense mechanics to a First Person Shooter requires too much suspension of disbelief to operate soundly.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												This is a neutral review, even if I placed it negatively.Overview of Sanctum 2 - The Bumbling Monster Tower Defence game. I played this game when it went on the weekend sale of Jan 25 - 26, of 2014, as of now, its locked and requires purchase to continue.Graphics:This game... it looks 'Ok', the AA is meh, the graphics don't really detect your optimal settings so you might have to adjust this on the first boot of the game. Textures are meh as well, I don't think you would notice it much either while playing.Gameplay:Gameplay is mostly about tower defence as it was branded, the FPS mechanism  is there as well, a rather odd one, you can basically do the first level of any stage just with your guns, however, you rely on this progressively as you play. The guns are mostly bad in their starting shape, the extra secondary guns were better, the rocket gun was nice, then you got the Prototype Lighting gun, which was awesome, however, you do NOT get much XP from it. Either this was a method to balance the gun (you just sat there and fried enemies), or something else with a similar aspect. The perks mechanism is odd, mostly you do not notice this at all, mostly they simply gave stuff like more damage every 3 shots. You get a limited amount of slots for your towers, which you unlock as you level up. This is ok IMO. AI/ Logic:This is where the game mostly sinks. At first when I started into the game, I am greeted with dancing men. (screenshot was not provided because I forgot to upload it when I 'had' the game) I was... well OK, great, dancing men, then I saw a man running around in a circle like an idiot. It just left me a peferct taste in my mouth. Then I entered the game itself, more problems.http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198033530482/screenshot/612789213469161154I saw that my comrades were bulky spacemen with yellow eyes,  and did not know how to handle beyond a pistol. Great. Then I saw they died almost immedietly after a wave of monsters spawned. I supposed that added more to their value: nothing. Spacemen are usually like those in ME3 or Halo, defeatable but brave and standing, I got nothing but bumbling idiots. Towers:The towers are somewhat limited. In your starting position you are given a gattling gun and a rocket launcher. Later on you get more towers to your collection. They are mostly limited to a general 5 meter range. Even the largest and most perked gun didn't surpass this. The thing that did was a earthquake machine that did some damage to the enemies. It appears (quoting CyanideBillzard here), that Sanctum 1 had a better assortment of towers as well in terms of range and varierty. Monster AI:The monsters are fine, but mostly just a running animal that wants to destory the core, there is nothing wrong with that except that perhaps that an element of randomness could have been added, the badass warriors could have lept over the walls, flying monsters could have had more attacking AI, rihnos could have smashed walls. Perhaps I was too early in the game to see more advanced AI, but this is my opinion of the initial monsters. I was also pleased when I saw that the boss did bother to destroy all the towers, makes him look like an idiot, because naturally all the bosses go directly to the goal(AKA, the core). This boss didn't.Hardware abuse:Although I am running on a GTX 660M with 8GB of RAM, I suppose some lower end units might feel the pain, some people were complaining about lag. I didn't really notice much.Bugs:To be surprised I did encounter some. For example, some enemies did stupid things like taking a longer walk around the corner, I was flown into a fence and got myself stuck there( had to suicide to get out), and my shotgun got stuck in the tower creation mode. 


this game is bugged 
A Screenshot of Sanctum 2
By: Lot Creator




The multiplayer.The multiplayer is there, but it feels artificial.  I found the multiplayer communication in this game several times worst than any other game I have played in my life. There is no way of communicating with the other players(or if there is, I never noticed it or I'd knew where to input my help). The team works independently and you have very little idea what to do, just believe the team has a general idea in 1 minute. Also, be fast, or people will start to hit enter and the game starts regardless if you still haven't upgraded your turrets.Overall:5/10 game, - Game Feels like: It was a game you play, but you don't feel like you played it or will... in a long time. **This of course is my opinion and you are subject to see fit as how you please to read this review. This review was meant to extract the game's faults and pluses.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I was going to write a good review and recommend this game for being decent and worth buying during a sale, but then I reached the Abandoned Lab level.This level shows how very flawed the game is:- Bad movement compared to similar titles (Orcs Must Die)You have the ability to jump, but I would not recommend you use it. Especially if you are using a weapon with any sort of knockback. Half the time you are going to get stuck in textures, fall off the map or just fall directly through it. This is not apparent in the early levels which are simple and flat, but as soon as you reach a map with multiple props or walls... Good luck, just good luck there, buddy. Impossible to play Sweet without getting stuck, unless you're high enough to change primary weapons. Also, bouncing pads? Bugged as hell. Rather than shooting you to their determined destination, they just bounce you up a tiny bit and then either cause you to drop down into enemies and get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by enemies OR keep you bouncing for a good 10 secs, letting the enemies destroy your core before you can intercept them.- Without DLC, you're going to have a bad time.There's little weapon variety and useful perks in vanilla Sanctum 2. Soloing the hardest maps (even without any Feats of Strength) is going to be extremely frustrating without DLC weapons and perks... and even if you do have those... have fun grinding for hours on end to unlock them!- Multiplayer? Multiplayer is a joke. I understand that it's a great thing if you play with a friend - and some levels are extremely difficult without co-op, but playing with 4 people quickly becomes a cluster♥♥♥♥, especially since enemies seem to get 10x hp. The 15 tower limit stays the same, so you will cap it very early unless you just pump all your resources into overcharging maxed towers - and believe me, you will be doing this most of the time in multiplayer. If you do play Multiplayer, do not play with random people. It will be horrible.- Limited towers? Another annoying thing is that you will be stuck with only 4 towers to take into your game. Really doesn't give much variety. The standard cookie-cutter build is Amp + Lightning + Scatter + Kairos.  Incidentally, some of the best towers outside this selection are DLC-only. ALSO, you will usually get the same amount of resources every wave, regardless of whether it's the first or the last. With the lower max level for towers, this is understandable, but it sometimes feels like you could have done a lot better if you had 50 more for an extra tower or upgrade.EDIT: Not to mention the computer resource drains if you alt-tab this game. First time I ever experienced that every single program would lock up and an on-going voice chat would lag in sync with the game's dropped framerate.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												I'll start by saying that I have never played Sanctum 1, and write this review for other people like me who are new to the franchise.As a tower defense game, it does little to reward creativity, and as a FPS it does little to reward skill.Maps are typically open, allowing for a standard horizontal-maze style defense which is mathematically optimal in every scenario for creating the longest creep path. Different tower types are similar in damage and upgrade potential, making a choice in towers somewhat meaningless. Different styles of towers are geared towards different mobs, but one is nearly equivalent to any other against all mob types in many cases; at least for three of the most obvious choices in primary damage towers.Character choice is extremely unbalanced, with the shotgun-wielding character capable of dropping the toughest creep in the game in a single shot, and all other characters being far less effective than a single tower. This makes the only important skill in the FPS side of the game being in the right place at the right time to drop the tough mobs.Social aspects of the game are emphasized and facilitated well by the UI, with an effective (and kind of funny) text-to-speech program, and public matchmaking. However, addition of more players limits the ability for a group to think through tower defense design since build time is limited (loosely though, plenty of time for an individual to plan the field), and building resources are automatically divided amongst players.Sanctum 2 may be a fun game for players who are playing with people they know, who can organize a well thought out tower defense layout in a relatively short amount of time, but other games such as Dungeon Defenders offer more potential for skill, creativity and character development.No offense to Coffee Stain, but they should be spending more time with great (and hilarious) games like Goat Simulator.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Let me preface by saying that I would not recommend any tower defence games on Steam. I love tower defence games, and none of them measure up.If you think the idea of Sanctum--tower defence with first person shooting--sounds interesting, then play this game. It's a big improvement over the first game.However. . I found the game a bit unstable. It crashed maybe 50% of the levels I played. Now, my computer is getting outdated, and I'm going to build a new system soon, which would likely improve this issue, however, you should be aware of this if you're only meeting the minimum requirements.I found the levels themselves to be too short. I played through about half the campaign. Levels rarely have even a dozen waves to them. I want to fight through, like, 50 waves. I never have enough gold to populate my maze with even a dozen towers, especially if some need to be upgraded. Often my mazes are only half finshed, if that. I'll enter a level, and plan out in my head the form the maze will take; establishing towers that will be extra effective as the maze doubles back on itself, but the level is over before the maze reaches that point. Although I didn't get to the end of the game, I never felt like I got to go out all, and only in one of the levels can I say I build a maze that was like the maze of my dreams. All the other levels just end too soon! Though, to the games credit, the level design themselves are really good. Actually, like, really, really good. There's a lot of variety, and they never feels like I'm playing the same levels I've played in a hundread other tower defence games. It's just that the levels end too soon; I never get to appreciate their designs. I can understand that, doubling the number of towers, and the number of enemies, may cause some issues, so it is understandable, however I'm left feeling like the levels are cut short. Another issue is that there's no in-level save. It's a good thing the levels aren't any longer, really! If your game crashes, or if you lose a level for any reason, then you have to play the whole thing over again! That can get frustrating. Especially if you only lose at the last wave because you anticipated something wrong, so now you have to rebuild the same exact maze and do everything over again, only on the last level build one tower differently, or something like that. It's just frustrating. Although it's nice getting to build a maze differently, it sucks when the game crashes and you have to play the level over again.A lot of the other things in the game are well done, and make the game stand out as a very unique entity. It feels very personal: with so many ways to loadout your character, and that gives you a lot of freedom in the game. It's very relaxing to play; I've enjoyed playing it a lot, it's just not meeting my desires for tower defence planning.The game looks and sounds great. If you want to play something different; something that you can play multiplayer cooperative with your friends, then this game is a great choice. I hope there will be a Sanctum 3. This game has been a great improvement over the first game. With levels that let you build more complex mazes, it would be an easy buy. I feel tower defence fanatics will feel the levels are unfinished when they end so soon, though people looking to casually play a game with friends will have a wonderful time here.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Sanctum 2 has terrible Linux support.  Not only does it run much less smoothly than its Windows counterpart, it frequently crashes.  On some levels (such as "Canopy") it will crash 100% of the time.  Changing the MPAA graphic setting also reliably causes a crash.  Sometimes the game will freeze, making you forcefully close it, or X server must be restarted, or the OS must be restarted entirely.  No combination of GPU drivers, GPU settings or game graphics settings resolves this.Sanctum 2 is brought to you by the same developers as Goat Simulator, the game that's so buggy users have decided (as you will see from MetaCritic reviews) that they must have developed it buggy >>on purpose<< as a joke.  But the joke is on us, the consumers, for paying for such shoddy software as this developer puts out and refuses to fix.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2013
												A complete 180 in game design for the worse. The original Sanctum was a great change of pace for tower defense games, putting you into the battlefield with upgradable weapons (a tower defense with shooting). Sanctum 2 takes the original's premise too far in the opposite direction in terms of game balance. Sadly, all the towers are too weak and this has become a first person shooter with towers. With very limited resources and base blocks, you will be building or upgrading on average one tower per wave with mazes only becoming effective near the end of the map. Even when you do finally make a great maze that is somewhat defensible, many of the bosses can smash their way through your base blocks, destroying your towers and creating a free path for enemies. The worst part is the difficulty curve; the early levels are tutorial-esque cakewalks which quickly drop off into frustrating trial-and-error tests of endurance.The map design has improved significantly, including 16 levels with improved music and sound providing great atmosphere. While the drawn slideshow cutscenes are entertaining and provide some pretense for the missions, the story and characters are never really fleshed out. Sanctum 2 combines sub-par FPS elements with sub-par RPG elements and sub-par TD elements to create... a surprisingly mediocre game. This could've been a fantastic co-op game if they just built on the original's game design instead of going for the CoD/console audience.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												Sanctum 2 is not about tower defense, it's about monotonously shooting waves and waves of enemies with sub-par guns and grinding your way to decent towers so that some day, you might be able to play a game that starts to look like it could be called a tower-defense game. Instead of unlocking towers per map (Like Defense Grid 2 did), you only unlock towers and weapons by leveling. This means, in theory, that you could grind level 1 over and over and have all the towers. It also means that if you don't like grinding and just want to play through the game, you'll be stuck with some very basic towers, upgrades and weapons that may not suit your play style.The updated graphics and larger array of weapons, playable classes, passive abilities and towers does not make the game feel any less inherently broken."Boss" creatures can break through your walls and towers and seeing as they can do so rather randomly, they might end up targetting vital blocks forcing you to pretty much restart your game because all of a sudden your initial investments become a complete waste of money. Some maps are well-designed and fun to play but a lot of maps are either an exercise in boredom or an exercise in futility as you struggle to find the tower set-up that the developers had in mind when they created the map.Your main weapon can never be exchanged, only your sidearm can. Unfortunately, there's no way to upgrade your main weapon and although powerful, it will never evolve to deal with situations on the battlefield. Instead, memorisation of enemies is key. If you enjoy running around and holding down the left mouse button constantly listening to lasers go "pew pew" constantly and putting very little though into creating and optimizing your tower maze then Sanctum 2 is for you.Everyone else should just avoid it unless it's for sale with a 80% discount or higher, go play Defense Grid 2 instead.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Played this game for many hours. It is very fun, addictive, and enjoyable. But I discovered the further you get, the more Sanctum 2 has a distinct identity crisis. The cohesion of FPS and tower defense breaks down becoming dysfunctional.This results in the biggest problem Sanctum 2 has: its difficulty curve. The game gets disproportionately more difficult the further you get. Eventually it gets to a point where it becomes impossible to beat levels solo. Eventually it even gets too hard to beat a level in co-op. A lot of this deals with the unreasonable restrictions Sanctum 2 places on players. Some of these are due to Sanctum 2 being designed with a heavy bias towards co-op play. Others are the foolish methods to control which genre the game is trying to beFor example- There are tons of towers available to unlock, but you're limited to using 4 at a time relying on co-op parters using their 4 tower slots to fill in your deficiencies.- You're encouraged to corral enemies in an enormous maze BUT- There's a low restriction on the number of turrets that can be placed. - Not all turrets are created equally. Some are weak and meant to be replaced by a stronger tower as you unlock them. Unfortunately ranking up is unreasonably slow and requires grinding.- Not all FPS weapons are created equally. Some characters feature a default weapon (the one you can't change) that is useless weak garbage.- Certain enemies were designed to bypass turret defenses throwing favor towards FPS elements- A few of these FPS specific enemies result in a very uneven increase in enemy strength.- Certain enemies are just plain bawllshiat. Specifically bobblehead enemies that take zero damage from turrets, and can only be damaged and killed by shooting their extremely tiny and constantly moving weak point.-Some of the later stages you will find yourself losing (typically near the end) because of a wave of these same stupid enemies that take the burden of defeat off your turrets and place it squarely on the player's FPS skills.The sad thing is I actually like Sanctum 2. It is a good game! I would recommend it if it didn't get so hard for stupid reasons so early in its campaign. That just kills the enjoyment got out of it. If you wish to get Sanctum 2, thankfully it tends to go on sale frequently. The base price for the core game is extremely high and not worth it.

number of helpful: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Generally a unsatisfying experience. I'll try cut it short and put down the ways that make the game something I cannot recommend.The level design is unenjoyable. While it trys to escape from the tropes of regular tower defense ways, the method it does it just doesn't quite work as well as it could. The thing that makes a good tower map layout is loops. Causing the mobs to go round and round hitting the same turrets as many times as you can. But many of the maps don't really allow for this, while there is certainly some room for loops often I found the shapes to have these awkward little spots where you just can't make the loop work and room goes to waste.There are ways that you can screw yourself over if you build up a maze in a certain way and in the next turn the game changes the flow of monsters in a way that means your high powered turrets aren't being used and you have to panick while enemies bash away at the powercore while you try to pick them off with your weapons. I understand that the game wants you to adjust your maze in major ways between waves, but sometimes I've built it in a certain way that I just can't or I'd rather not.The special enemy types can be frustrating to take down. There is an armoured one will armour everywhere except a little spot on it's rear, so you'll be running behind it shooting away at it, and when the enemy hits a corner it will suddenly snap to a new angle. There's no smooth rotation, it's just bam, it's now at a new angle and now you have to move to compensate for this. All of which might just be okay, but perhaps you've built a maze with many angled corners. Now the monster will be snapping to new angles every few seconds while you're trying to shoot away at it's rear. The only way to do a significant amount of damage is on straights. Ahh it's just frustating.The sound design is lacking, especially in the weapons. I can't quite put my finger on what it is exactly, perhaps the lack of punch that makes you feel like you're actually making a dent.I didn't like having abilities that and towers make you more effective and make the game more fun locked off until you put in the required time to unlock them. Some people like this.. and I know it was designed to keep you engaged and also to make you to try some unlocks that maybe you wouldn't use.. but I just don't like these systems.It really feels like this genre could be something special, but I can't see that something in this game. Perhaps another studio will be able to fill that hole.I played it for two hours with a friend and another three on my own and I've found that it wasn't something I found fun, which is too bad.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I can't think of a single game in my library that made me say: "I really regret purchasing that." Sanctum 2 does just that. The game it self doesn't even feel or look finished. The animations are poor, and the "cutscenes" or "story line" is made up of a couple of images with text bubbles. Alot of things felt like they were just place holders and that this game didn't get the attention it needed. The barrier building and upgrading isn't fun or exciting because the pathfinding for the AI just charges through whatever maze you make. Once you've made one maze though, you've made them all. The game lacks variety. The good news is, there is still a little bit of a community that continues to play. So it's not hard to find a game if you are interested in getting it.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Sanctum 2 is the sequel to the world’s first Tower Defense/FPS hybrid game. Pick from four unique character classes and embark on a mission to protect the oxygen-producing Cores from hordes of deadly aliens who are threatened by their existence. Outfit your character exactly the way you want through the new and extensive customization system. Choose your own loadout of towers, weapons and perks, but choose wisely because you are humanity’s last defense against the unrelenting hordes set out to destroy it. Sanctum 2 is a new game completely rebuilt from the ground up using community feedback and innovative design to really push the bar of what an independent studio can do.In Sanctum 2, you will utilize elements from multiple gameplay genres to succeed. Construct towers and walls during the building phase before the enemies attack, then jump into the fray and blast everything to pieces in FPS mode. You can progress through the single-player campaign yourself, or play with up to four friends in co-op to discover the secrets of the planet LOEK III and learn the backstory on why the aliens are so intent on destroying the Cores you are sworn to protect.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												Boooring. I tried this during the free week for the hell of it, and it's as mediocre a shooter as they come. No special gameplay features to set it apart from anything you've played in the last ten years of FPS's. Plus, even with graphics turned down, it chugs like a frieght train. If you're a complete tower defense fanatic, it might do something for you... I guess.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												Sanctum 2 seems to draw inspiration from the most mediocre tower defense and fps games to deliver a bland experience. The shooting mechanics are floaty at best and unfulfilling, and the defense options are overly simplistic. I do enjoy the class system, but a great opportunity to fleshed them out with unique towers is squandered.The game isn't necessarily horrible, but I would expect more from a sequel to a popular game. Orcs Must Die and similar games offer a much better experience.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												This game is pretty dumb. I got it in a bundle and thought I'd give it a try since I do like shooters, and you'd think an FPS/Tower Defense hybrid could be cool, right?Wrong. Unless of course you like shooters where you can't possibly die and are pretty much ignored by the enemy, who just runs along a pre-determined path around your barricades just to attack your core.They could have simply left the shooting the player does out of it, and just had it be a tower defense game with a unique camera angle for all the good it does you.If you like Tower Defense, you might like this. But if you're looking at it for an FPS experience, I would advise you to look somewhere else.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Sanctum 1 was 100x better...Pros:Better graphics/animationsHealth bar that shows how much health enemies have, in numbersCons:Have to unlock weapons and towers before you can use themYou can be killed by monsters? Seriously? Who thought that would be a good idea?Towers are smallerEnemies are smaller and harder to hitEverything is smaller, it just feels crampedYou can't teleport around by going into overviewIf you can get a teleport tower, you have to unlock it first... but I haven't played enough of the game to get that far, and I don't really have any desire to play this game anymoreOverall, the gameplay is less emersive and harder to follow than Sanctum 1. What I loved about the original Sanctum was how simple and easy to get into it was...Sanctum 1 was 10/10, this I would give maybe 3.5/10. Really a huge let-down and dissapointment. Save your money.
